scenario_title: Single-Event IP Theft by Disgruntled Engineer Incite Defection

why.details: The insider aimed to use stolen intellectual property to create a competing product, driven by financial ambition and personal dissatisfaction with the employer.

how.description: Recruited colleagues who are willing to assist in accessing and downloading sensitive data.
how.procedure: Insider cultivates relationships or manipulates colleagues to obtain access or credentials via social engineering or peer coercion.
observable_evidence: Unusual internal communications soliciting help for access
Colleagues providing credentials or delegating rights
Access requests deviating from normal workflows
how.impact: Acquires foothold through trusted internal collaborator, facilitating subsequent higher-privilege actions.

how.description: Used company email to request admin-level access to project resources under the pretense of project continuity.
how.procedure: Insider leverages existing or manipulated credentials, or persuades administrators to grant elevated permissions using misleading justification.
observable_evidence: Email requests for elevated access citing project needs
Granting of admin or high privileged accounts not following standard change control
how.impact: Elevated privileges allow deeper access to sensitive repositories and data, increasing risk of large scale exfiltration.

how.description: Downloaded confidential files from internal systems and copied them to a private external storage device.
how.procedure: Insider uses elevated rights to locate and download high-value IP/data and transfers it via removable media or personal external storage/cloud, often in a single event operation.
observable_evidence: Large volume file read/copy operations from sensitive directories
USB device insertion or external storage access events
Outbound data transfers to personal cloud or non-corporate domains
how.impact: Significant intellectual property loss, competitive disadvantage, legal/regulatory exposure for the organization.
